name: Edinburgh
fun_fact: Fun fact: Traditional haggis was banned in the United States from 1971 to 2022 because it contains sheep lungs - but Edinburgh restaurants kept serving the authentic recipe, and locals claim you haven't truly tried haggis unless you've eaten it in Scotland with a dram of whisky and a recitation of Robert Burns' 'Address to a Haggis.'

hero_dishes.name: Haggis, Neeps & Tatties
hero_dishes.description: Sheep's heart, liver, and lungs minced with onions, oatmeal, suet, and spices, cooked in sheep's stomach. Served with mashed turnips (neeps) and potatoes (tatties).
hero_dishes.origin_story: Scotland's national dish has been celebrated since Robert Burns wrote 'Address to a Haggis' in 1786. The mixture creates a rich, savory, slightly spicy flavor that's distinctly Scottish. While the ingredients sound intimidating, properly prepared haggis is delicious and central to Scottish identity.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: The Arcade Bar (considered best in capital, 100+ whiskeys), Makars Mash Bar (TripAdvisor Awards 2018-2024), The Haggis Box (Royal Mile, takeaway boxes)

hero_dishes.name: Princess Diana Style Haggis
hero_dishes.description: Haggis served with special cream sauce infused with tomatoes, onions, and Drambuie liqueur.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A modern Edinburgh creation at The Arcade Bar that elevates traditional haggis with a luxurious Drambuie cream sauce. The name honors Princess Diana, and the dish represents contemporary Scottish cooking respecting tradition while innovating.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: The Arcade Bar (specializes in haggis variations, vegetarian versions available)

hero_dishes.name: Haggis Bon Bons at The Doric
hero_dishes.description: Small balls of haggis rolled in pinhead oats, deep-fried, served with string potatoes and creamed turnips.
hero_dishes.origin_story: The Doric, built in the 17th century and serving classic Scottish dishes since the 18th century, modernized haggis presentation with these bite-sized appetizers. They maintain tradition while making haggis approachable for first-timers.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: The Doric (historic pub serving since 18th century)

hero_dishes.name: Cullen Skink
hero_dishes.description: Traditional Scottish soup made with smoked haddock, potatoes, onions, and cream. Thick, warming, coastal comfort food.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Originating from the town of Cullen in northeastern Scotland, this soup represents Scottish fishing heritage. The smoked haddock gives it a distinctive flavor that's become an Edinburgh staple.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: The Halfway House (one of Edinburgh's smallest pubs, award-winning), traditional Scottish pubs throughout the city

signature_drinks.name: Scottish Whisky
signature_drinks.description: Single malts and blended Scotch whiskies from regions across Scotland - Speyside, Highland, Islay, Lowland.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with haggis as tradition demands. The Arcade Bar has over 100 whiskeys. Locals drink whisky neat or with a splash of water, never ice. Whisky and haggis together is the ultimate Scottish experience.

signature_drinks.name: Irn-Bru
signature_drinks.description: Scotland's 'other national drink' - a bright orange, sweet carbonated soft drink with an indescribable flavor.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Consumed as a hangover cure and general refreshment. Fiercely protected as Scottish identity. Made in Scotland from girders (according to the advertising).

food_culture_notes: Burns Night (January 25) is when haggis reaches peak importance - restaurants are packed with people celebrating Robert Burns
Vegetarian and vegan haggis is widely available and taken seriously - Makars and others offer excellent plant-based versions
Live music accompanies dining at many traditional pubs like The White Hart (nightly live music)
Edinburgh's food scene blends centuries-old traditions (The Doric since 17th century) with contemporary innovation (Wedgwood fine dining)
